awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a Long-range Airborne Snow and Sea Ice Thickness Observing System (LASSITOS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Accurate knowledge of sea ice thickness over large scales is crucial for understanding the current and future states of the Arctic ice cover, and for near- and long-term predictions of Arctic marine environments. With the Arctic ice pack undergoing a major transition from perennial to seasonal ice, ice thickness - more so than ice extent - is a key variable  describing the state and evolution of the ice-ocean system. However, methods of observing sea ice thickness at regional or basin scales with sufficient accuracy and resolution to capture growth and melt processes, detect hazards, or assess habitat quality are lacking. This project will develop an Airborne electromagnetic (AEM) snow radar system capable of being integrated into long-range Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS). This will allow acquisition of basin-scale ice thickness and snow depth data as part of a network for Arctic observations that addresses information needs of researchers, local communities and industry. This MRI development project will contribute to NSF's Navigating the New Arctic Big Idea. 

AEM methods offer a novel means of measuring sea ice thickness over the full range of thicknesses found in the Polar Regions. By remotely sensing the positions of the upper and lower surfaces of the ice cover, AEM measurements typically achieve an accuracy of better than 10% of the total thickness, with less sensitivity to uncertainties in snow cover or sea surface topography. Development and commissioning of the Long-range Airborne Snow and Sea Ice Thickness Observing System (LASSITOS) will also provide opportunities for education and training, including capstone projects for the University of Alaska Fairbanks' new minor in aeronautical engineering and student involvement in comprehensive calibration/validation field activities. LASSITOS is expected to generate interest among native students from coastal villages in northern Alaska, who represent another key stakeholder group for sea ice information. The leader of this project is an early-career researcher.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Overview

 The outcome of this project is a new drone-deployable instrument for measuring ice thickness and snow depth over Arctic sea ice, which we have named the Lightweight Airborne Snow and Sea Ice Thickness Observing System (LASSITOS). At this stage, the LASSITOS instrument is composed of two sub-systems, the LEM and the LSR (see Fig. 1), which are carried on separate unmaned aerial vehicles (UAVs). The LEM gets its name from the electromagnetic (EM) sounder that allows it to measure the distance to the seawater below the ice (hw). At the same time, a laser altimeter measures the distance to the top of the snow (ha) and the difference between these two measurements represents the total thickness of ice and snow (hT). The LASSITOS snow radar (LSR) penetrates the snow on top of the sea ice and measure its depth and surface elevation. 

When originally conceived, the “L” in LASSITOS was intended to stand for “long-range” and we planned to integrate the LEM directly into a long-range fixed-wing UAV. However, we found that even small carbon fiber airframes would produce unacceptable interfererence with the EM signal from the ocean and so we needed a tether to separate the LEM from its UAV. This made long-range, low-altitude operations with a fixed-wing aircraft impractible and so we refocused our efforts toward making the system lightweight and compatible with a smaller class of multirotor UAVs. This provided the additional benefits of greater manueverability for dense 2D mapping of the ice thickness and simplified integration and operation, which makes it more practicable for operation by local communities or in remote locations.

 

Specifications and accuracy

The LEM is able to operate at 8 discrete frequencies in the 0.6-8 kHz range. Although only a single frequency can be broadcast at a time, they can be switched rapidly enough to allow effectively simultaneous measurements with up to 3 different frequencies. Results from “calibration climbs” over level sea ice and open water demonstrates an accuracy in the measurement of hw of better than 10% at all frequencies for hw up to 12 m. Accounting for pitch and roll of the UAV, the laser altimeter typically measures the distance to the snow surface, ha, of < 2cm. The accuracy of the freeboard measurement depends on the uncertainties in both the laser altimeter and the GNSS position. Using real time kinematic (RTK) corrections, the freeboard error can be reduced to approximately 5 cm. This is sufficient for mapping surface topography of thicker ice or identifying freeboard differences between, for example, level first year ice and thicker multiyear ice.

 

The LSR uses a frequency modulated continuous wave (FMCW) ku-band radar with a modest bandwidth of 1.5 GHz, which is the result of hardware compromises to keep the system within the weight limits for FAR Part 107 rules (55 lb total take-off weight). In this configuration, the LSR is able to resolve snow depths greater than approximately 25 cm. Below this depth, the reflections from the air-snow and snow-ice interfaces cannot be readily distinguished. We also tested an ultra-broadband (16-18 GHz) version of the LSR installed on a snow mobile. Although further miniaturization is required to install this system on a UAV, we demonstrated that is able to resolve snow depths over sea ice with an accuracy of approximately 5cm.

 

Example field data

Final field testing of the LASSITOS instrument was performed over landfast sea ice near Utqiagvik in April 2024. This included airborne and snow mobile-based surveys with the LEM and LSR over 2-km transect extending from the shoreline across both level and deformed first year sea ice. Figure 2 compares LASSITOS measurements along the first 800 m of this transect with in situ validation observations. Overall, the LEM measurements of total snow-plus-ice thickness, hw, agree with drill hole measurements to within better than 20 cm. However, we note there is a frequency dependent response to water depths less than approximately 3 m. We anticipate this will allow independent determination of water depth and ice thickness in shallow regions. The snow depth was generally too shallow in this region for the LSR to resolve, but the ultra-broadband system mounted on a snow machine accurately captured the variability recorded by the Magnaprobe.

A second, LEM-only transect was flown over a pressure ridge with all 8 frequencies (see Fig. 3), showcasing the ability to successfully to measure both total thickness, hw, and freeboard over a wide range of ice thickness. The measured thickness is consistent for all frequencies at the margins of the ridge, but the higher frequencies underestimate thickness over the thickest part of the keel. We attribute this to the presence of conductive water in the porous keel and we anticipate a multi-frequency approach may allow estimates of ridge keel porosity.
